title: Leopard Gecko Feeding Guide: Complete Insectivore Diet & Supplementation
description: Evidence-based feeding guide for leopard geckos covering live insect diet, age-based feeding schedules, portion sizing, calcium/multivitamin supplementation, gut-loading, and body condition assessment.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Complete Insectivore Diet for Leopard Geckos
content.content: Leopard geckos are obligate insectivores, requiring a diet of live, moving insects to trigger hunting behaviors and provide complete nutrition. Unlike crested geckos, they cannot survive on prepared powdered diets—they must eat whole insects. Proper feeding encompasses more than just offering bugs: it requires age-appropriate schedules, calcium supplementation to prevent metabolic bone disease, gut-loading feeder insects for optimal nutrition, and portion control to maintain healthy body condition. This guide provides evidence-based feeding protocols for all life stages.
Leopard geckos hunt live insects in the wild, consuming beetles, crickets, and other invertebrates. Captive diet must replicate this nutritional profile.

content.text: Primary Feeder Insects (Ranked by Nutritional Value):

rows: Staple feeder—best Ca:P ratio, low chitin, nutrient-dense
Staple feeder—readily available, good activity level
Supplemental—poor Ca:P, high chitin, use sparingly
Treats only—high fat, aggressive (can bite gecko)
Treats/hydration—85% moisture, rapid growth requires frequent feeding

content.content: Do NOT feed: Wild-caught insects (pesticide risk), fireflies/lightning bugs (FATAL—contain lucibufagin toxin), king mealworms (aggressive), waxworms as staple (extremely high fat 22%), or freeze-dried insects as sole diet (leopard geckos rarely recognize non-moving food).
Feeding frequency and insect size change dramatically throughout a leopard gecko's life. Overfeeding juveniles stunts growth; overfeeding adults causes obesity.

content.text: Life Stage Feeding Guidelines:

rows: 1/4" or smaller (1-week crickets, small dubia nymphs)
Calcium + D3 at every feeding OR Repashy Calcium Plus daily
2 insects per 1" length OR 15 minutes feeding
Calcium + D3 every other feeding, multivitamin 1x/week
2 insects per 1" OR until satiated (10-15 min)
2 insects per 1" OR 6-10 insects per feeding
Calcium + D3 at EVERY feeding, multivitamin 2x/week

content.content: The '2 insects per inch of length' rule is a reliable guideline: a 7" adult receives 14 insects per feeding (every 3-4 days). Alternatively, offer insects for 15 minutes, removing leftovers. Adjust based on body condition—ribs visible = underfed, fat bulges at tail base/armpits = overfed.
Insect size relative to gecko size affects safety and digestion. The 'space between eyes' rule prevents choking/impaction.

content.text: Insect Size Limits by Gecko Size:

rows: 1-week crickets, small dubia nymphs, fruit fly pupae
2-3 week crickets, medium dubia nymphs, small BSFL
3-4 week crickets, large dubia nymphs, mealworms
Adult crickets, adult dubia, superworms (head removed), hornworms

content.content: Insects wider than the space between the gecko's eyes can cause choking or impaction. When in doubt, size down. Smaller insects = safer, even if you need to offer more. Superworms can bite—remove head or use only for large adults.
Feeder insects are calcium-deficient and require supplementation to prevent metabolic bone disease (MBD). With UVB lighting, reduce D3 supplementation; without UVB, increase D3 frequency.

content.text: Supplementation Schedule WITH UVB Lighting:

rows: Rep-Cal Calcium (no D3), Zoo Med ReptiCalcium
Primary calcium source, UVB synthesizes D3 naturally
Rep-Cal with D3, Zoo Med ReptiCalcium with D3
Backup D3 source for low UVB days
Zoo Med Reptivite (without D3), Arcadia EarthPro-A
Vitamin A, E, B-complex for immune function, eye health

content.text: Supplementation Schedule WITHOUT UVB Lighting:

rows: Simplifies schedule—contains higher D3 for non-UVB setups

content.content: All-in-one supplements (Repashy Calcium Plus LoD with UVB, Calcium Plus without UVB) simplify schedules dramatically. Use 'LoD' (low D3) version if providing UVB lighting, regular strength if no UVB. Apply via 'shake and bake' method: place insects in bag/cup with powder, shake gently.
Insects are nutritionally poor unless fed high-quality diet before feeding to geckos. Gut-loading transfers nutrients from insect gut to gecko.

content.text: Gut-Loading Protocol:

rows: Repashy Superload, Cricket Crack, Fluker's High Calcium
Mix with water to form paste, offer 24-48 hrs before feeding
Collard greens, mustard greens, turnip greens
Chopped small, offer 24 hrs before feeding
Water gel crystals, wet sponge, moisture-rich veggies

content.content: Do NOT gut-load with: iceberg lettuce (no nutrition), spinach (oxalates bind calcium), cabbage (goitrogens), or dog/cat food (too high protein, causes uric acid buildup in geckos). Focus on calcium-rich greens and commercial gut-load products.
Feeding techniques affect stress levels, hunting behavior, and insect escapees. Different methods suit different keeper preferences.

content.text: Feeding Method Comparison:

rows: Contains insects, reduces escapees, easy portion control
Limits hunting behavior, some insects (mealworms) may escape
Dubia roaches, mealworms, BSFL (less active insects)
Escapees hide in enclosure, crickets may bite gecko at night
Well-established adults in bioactive setups only
Ensures gecko eats, good for picky eaters, training opportunity
Juveniles, new geckos adjusting to captivity, sick geckos
No substrate ingestion risk, controls portions, easy cleanup
Geckos on sand/loose substrate, very young juveniles

content.content: Recommended for most keepers: Shallow dish (2-3" diameter, 1" high) for less active insects (dubia, mealworms), free-roaming for crickets in well-sealed enclosures. Remove uneaten crickets after 15 minutes to prevent nighttime biting of gecko.
Leopard geckos store fat in tails, but obesity affects joints and organs. Use visual and tactile cues to assess health.

content.text: Body Condition Scoring (1-5 Scale):

rows: Ribs, spine, hips clearly visible, tail thin and 'stick-like', sunken eyes
Bones easily felt with no muscle/fat covering
EMERGENCY: Vet visit required, increase feeding to daily, rule out parasites
Ribs and spine faintly visible, tail narrow but not stick-like
Bones felt with minimal tissue covering
Increase feeding frequency (daily for adults, 2x daily for juveniles)
Body smooth, no bones visible except slight hip bones, tail plump (carrot-shaped)
Bones felt with gentle pressure, good muscle tone
Rounded body, fat deposits in 'armpits', tail very thick (wider than head)
No bones felt without firm pressure, thick fat layer
Reduce feeding frequency (every 5-6 days), smaller portions
Bulging fat rolls, difficulty walking, tail massive (2x head width), fat 'bubbles' at base of tail
No bones felt, excessive fat deposits
VET VISIT: Risk of fatty liver disease, reduce to weekly feeding, offer low-fat insects only (crickets, dubia)

content.content: Tail loss resets body condition—regrown tails store less fat and look different (bulbous, shorter). Assess body condition using torso thickness, not just tail. Breeding females lose weight rapidly during egg production—score 2-3 is normal after laying.

content.text: Life Stage/Condition Adjustments:

rows: Unlimited food, calcium + D3 at every feeding
Normal diet, ensure hydration (humid hide access)
No change—appetite may decrease 1-2 days before shed
Gradually reduce feeding to weekly, then stop
Resume feeding slowly—every 3-4 days for 1 week, then normal
Liquid calcium (oral), slurry diet via syringe if not eating, vet guidance
Offer variety (try dubia instead of crickets), tong-feed, ensure temps 94-97°F
Adjust as needed—rule out illness first

content.text: Troubleshooting Feeding Issues:

rows: Temps too low (<85°F), stress, impaction, parasites, brumation
Check basking 94-97°F, reduce handling, palpate for impaction, fecal test, allow brumation if winter
Insects too large, temps too low, handling after feeding
Size down insects, ensure basking 94-97°F, wait 24 hrs after feeding to handle
Stress, overly aggressive prey (superworm biting gecko)
Use feeding tongs, avoid superworms, reduce handling, ensure gecko feels secure
Insufficient calcium supplementation, no UVB, all-mealworm diet
Vet visit immediately, increase calcium + D3 to every feeding, add UVB, switch to dubia/crickets
Overfeeding frequency, too many high-fat insects (superworms, waxworms)
Reduce to weekly feeding, crickets/dubia only, increase enclosure size for exercise
Substrate ingestion (loose substrate + low temps), insect too large
Vet visit, warm soaks, switch to tile substrate temporarily, ensure 94-97°F basking
Use 2-3" high dish, smooth interior (glass/ceramic), remove escapees to prevent night biting

content.content: Loss of appetite >2 weeks is NEVER normal (except during brumation). Rule out: low temperatures (<85°F basking), impaction (palpate abdomen), parasites (fecal test), husbandry stress (insufficient hides, no humid hide). If temps and husbandry are correct, vet visit required.

content.text: Essential Equipment & Supplies:

rows: Primary calcium source with UVB (2-3x/week adults)
Rep-Cal with D3 or Zoo Med with D3
Backup D3 source with UVB (1x/week) OR primary without UVB (2-3x/week)
Zoo Med Reptivite without D3 OR Arcadia EarthPro-A
Repashy Calcium Plus LoD (with UVB) OR Calcium Plus (no UVB)
Nutrient boost for insects 24-48 hrs before feeding

content.content: Monthly feeding cost estimate: $15-25 for adult gecko (dubia roaches or crickets), $5-10 for supplements (lasts 6-12 months). Buying feeder insects in bulk (500-1000 count) significantly reduces cost. Consider breeding dubia roaches if keeping multiple geckos.

content.text: Adult Leopard Gecko Weekly Feeding Schedule (WITH UVB):

rows: Multivitamin (Zoo Med Reptivite) OR Calcium WITH D3 (alternate weekly)

content.content: Feeding happens every 3-4 days (Monday, Thursday, Sunday pattern). Rotate supplement types. With UVB, use plain calcium most often; without UVB, use calcium + D3 instead of plain calcium.
